utterances: Yesterday, authorities in Afghanistan reportedly took steps to ban YouTube completely.

McLaughlin says in light of that kind of blanket ban, Google's policy of obliging governments with narrowly targeted takedowns actually may help preserve a forum for speech in countries like Egypt and Libya.
And while that's true, these targeted takedowns may also help Google's YouTube expand and preserve its market.
Steve Henn, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
We're glad you're joining us for a free discussion of the issues on this local public radio station supported by your community, which brings you MORNING EDITION.
You can continue to follow us throughout the day on social media.
We're on Facebook.
We're on Twitter.
You can find us, among other places, @MorningEdition and @NPRInskeep.
The record-breaking temperatures of the polar vortex caused much of the U.S.
to shut down earlier this week.
With so many schools and offices closed and flights canceled, the hit to the economy was in the billions.
But the deep freeze had at least one surprising upside, putting warm smiles on the faces of entomologists.
That's because it may have been cold enough to kill some damaging species of insects, including the tree-killing emerald ash borer.
From Chicago, NPR's David Schaper reports.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHOPPING)
Chopping into an ash tree with a hatchet in his frigid bare hands, Tom Tiddens(ph) peels back the bark, looking for emerald ash borer larva.
Tiddens is an entomologist and supervisor of plant health care at the Chicago Botanic Garden.
And in this wooded area just off a busy thoroughfare, emerald ash borers have been eating and destroying scores of native ash trees.
squiggly S-shaped trails where the larvae have been feasting, disrupting the flow of water and nutrients up the tree before they burrow into the bark.
There's one right there.
It's a small, white, worm-like creature about a half-an-inch long.
Yeah, there's one right here, and let's see if I can kind of pull him out for you.
Tiddens wants to see how this tiny but devastating insect has been faring through this week's bitter cold snap that sent temperatures here to 16 degrees below zero.
Many arborists are hoping that these tree-killing beetles are all freezing and dying off.
It turns out that that's not really the case.
This insect, like a lot of other insects, actually have a strategy for over-wintering.
He says the process called super-cooling begins in the fall.
They'll cease feeding.
It'll stay under the bark so it's protected there.
It will actually purge all the stomach contents of its gut because that could freeze.
And they actually fold themselves in half when they do that.
And sure enough, many of the larvae we find are folded up to try to stay alive.

Tiddens and other experts say temperatures inside the bark need to get to about 13 degrees below zero for the troublesome bugs to really begin dying off, and that means air temperatures need to be even colder than that, according to research biologist Rob Venette(ph).
So around minus-20, there can be as much as 50 percent mortality, and as temperatures approach minus-30, we can see nearly 100 percent mortality.
Venette works for the U.S.
Forest Service in Minnesota.
I'm probably one of the few people that really root for an extremely cold day because I really do think it helps with some of the major insect problems that we have.
Venette says it got cold enough in parts of Minnesota to possibly wipe out up to 80 percent of the emerald ash borer population and significantly slow the advance of the invasive insect there.

The cold may reduce the population by 10 to 20 percent in parts of southern Wisconsin, northern Illinois, Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, but Venette cautions that the cold is just a temporary setback for the emerald ash borer.
We're simply not having the cold weather that we've had in previous years.
So we can't count on the cold as being the solution to the problem.

Venette and other experts say this week's record-breaking cold might slow the spread of other invasive species, too, including the gypsy moth and the woolly adelgid, which has infested and killed hundreds of thousands of hemlock trees in the Northeast.
And the numbers of some kinds of ticks should be reduced by the bitter cold, too.
Another plus: biologist Greg Mueller at the Chicago Botanic Garden says the bitter cold won't hurt many beneficial species of insects, including pollinators such as honeybees.
They actually kind of cluster together and form a bee ball around the queen and then vibrate their wings, and that keeps the whole nest up at warm, in the 90s.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is NPR News.
Oh, dear.
Parents never want to let their kids down, but this holiday season, many parents face a sad reality.
Empty wallets will mean fewer presents.
So how do you talk to your kids about facing a lean holiday season?
We pose that question to our regular News & Notes contributor, Judge Lynn Toler, the star of TV's ""Divorce Court."" Hi, Lynn.
How are you, Farai?
I'm doing quite well, but there are a lot of folks who are really financially pinched.
And for better or worse, we live in a society where people are often judge by things.
And kids are no exception.
Kids can be really cruel, if you're wearing the wrong brand of sneakers or if you're - you got a toy, but it's the generic toy as opposed to some, you know, over-priced brand name toy.

Given how kids act, and given the realities of the moment, and given that gift giving is a part of the holiday season, how do you, if you're a parent, process the needs that you have to deal, with the very real bills, and to deal with the expectations of little people?
Well, I have couple of responses to that.
First of all, you give the hit to the persons or the people best able to take it.
We as parents - my husband and I may not exchange gifts this year.
We may exchange coupons for, I'll give you a coupon for going to a crash-and-smash movie with you, I'll go to a chic movie with you.
(unintelligible)
(Soundbite of laughter)
We can take it.
Do you know what I mean?
Right.
I gave my - one year, I gave my husband a coupon to allow him to smoke a cigar in the house during the game.
We were having a tough year that year, so - you know what I mean?
So there are things - we can take it.
So we can not spend on each other and still encourage our relationship, and it gives you an excuse to be even closer because it makes you come together.
And it all - when you talk to the children about it, it's all in how to sell it.
It's not, mommy doesn't have enough money this year.
It's, you know, this year we're going to do something different.
We're going to buy one great thing.
It's going to be a Wii game or whatever, and we're all going to play it, and we're going to spend our time doing this.
Or, I'm going to give you a coupon of sorts to do something one day off of school.
My 16-year-old would love that better than anything else in the world.
I'm just going to give you a one-day-off-of-school coupon.
So it's all on how you sell it.
Not that we are without this year, it's just, we're changing our game plan this year.
Do you think that kids panic when they get the sense that their parents are in hard times?
No doubt about it.
Kids panic.
Kids are scared to death.
You are their whole world, and they think that you're strong, mommy and daddy can do anything, they'll protect you from everything.
And when they see that you are weak, they get scared, because you are - they are - you are their everything.
So it's very important to keep that to yourself, and it's very important for you two to talk about it so you can assuage some of the angst by talking to one another, and not spreading that around.
So it's an idea of, it's not a tight Christmas, it's a different Christmas.
Maybe we'll go to a soup shelter and feed people.
So we can do what we always say we want to do, make it about the reason for the season, as opposed to the economics or the materialistic standpoint.
Sometimes people have thing that they fall back on that are healthy or unhealthy.
Some people I know when they become incredibly stressed out, become gym rats, and they're always exercising, and they actually in the best shape ever when they're stressed out.
Other people overeat, turn to alcohol or other things.
How - a lot of us lived also in extended families where you can tell when someone is doing better or worse.
How do you have a conversation if you think someone during a holiday season is kind of going in a direction that's not healthy for them or their family?
Are you all right, is a wonderful question.
It's something that everybody is afraid to ask, and it's not - are you OK?
And if you don't think they're OK, I said, I'm worried about you because I see you doing A, B and C.
And then always have an offer.
If they are stressed out because of A, B or C, if their - the kids, it's like, can I take your kids for awhile?
Can I help with this?
Can I help with that?
Can I get involved?
Can you get others involved, the whole family to come together to assist that person in whatever way you need.
I think a lot of women sometimes say, we've got to be perfect, we've got to do the right thing, I can't share my need.
Share, and you'd be surprised at what you get back.
And on the male side, they're often money, money, money, I am responsible, I am responsible.
Share your concern with your wife about your inabilities, and you'll be surprised at the ease that you feel simply by having that conversation.
Baby, I'm worried.
And go from there.
And what about if you see your community in need?
Maybe there is more people losing their houses, etc., etc., etc., and you're not a bottomless well of money, but you want to help.
How do you help?
You help by giving of your time.
If someone needs to take on an extra job, or if you have someone in the community - I have someone next door to me who is ill.
And I go over there, I'll do laundry, I will do, you know, whatever it does to take the edge off of it.
And it's amazing, if you just take little chores off of people who are having a big problem, the sense of relief that they have.
Babysitting for people who need to go out and take an extra job.
Whatever you need to do, but the small things count so much, because I think we have such a great sense of isolation in this society.
It's our family, it's our problem and we don't go beyond ourselves to assist and lend a hand.
And it is more than money, and I think if we can break down that sense of isolation, there is comfort in simply community that has nothing to do with a bank account.
Oh, it's a beautiful way to put it.
And there's going to be, I think, a lot of people bringing their best community spirit to the table this season, and so I certainly offer you mine, and good wishes to you and yours.
And the same to you.
Thank you.
That was TV's ""Divorce Court"" Judge Lynn Toler.
She's also the author of ""My Mother's Rules: A Practical Guide to Becoming an Emotional Genius."" And she spoke to us from KESZ in Phoenix, Arizona.
I don't think that's going to happen unless there's a credible threat of force, and right now, in fact, Assad is announcing he's won, that he's cleaned up the rebels from top towns, and he's won.
